div.p: itu "nāṭaka vaḻakkiṉum" (to.po.53) eṉṉuñ cūttirattup "pāṭalu ḷamaiyāta" eṉṟataṉāl ēṟu taḻuviyavāṟṟait tōḻi talaivikkuk kāṭṭik kūṟi, ikkuravaiyuḷ avaṉaip pāṭukam vāveṉṟāṭku, avaḷ uṭampāṭṭiṉuṭ tāṉ alaraccam nīṅkiṉamaiyum avaṉ taṉṉai varuttiṉamaiyuṅ kūṟip pāṭip piṉṉart tōḻi namar avaṟku niṉṉaik koṭainērntāreṉak kūṟiyatu.

lg.l: who appear in the clan that established the ancient fame
of the southern king of unfading glory, who made [his enemies] bow by the strength
of [his] shining fish [banner] that he impressed with [his] fame, repelling the bow along with the tiger,
so that the enemy land turned into [his] place, going at them without softening,
because the ocean has snatched his earth, [its] abundant waves mounting [it],
[and] with happy anticipation made [them] enter the arena:
the blameless white bull like the one of milk colour
with a shining resplendent palmyra banner [so] high as to reach the sky ,
the black bull abounding in power like the one with Śrī as a spot on [his] chest,
with the famous discus with golden ornaments that excelled in fighting hostilities,
the tawny bull abounding in hostility, like only the form of him with a third eye
on [his] forehead [and] a crescent moon that dwells in [his] very resplendent matted hair,
and the frightening red bull, like only the colour of him who masters the spear
in unyielding battle, who killed the mango [tree demon] so that the vast ocean was stirred up,
those with [such] qualities that fight thus and others,
like many shapely clouds that are assembled.
In that sequence, “he to whom will yield the neck of this one white bull
will obtain her who is beautiful [and has] thorn teeth.
He who takes with fear of [his] fury the black bull
with sharp horns will obtain sleep on the long-grown tresses of [her with] bright jewels.
He who will take this murderous bull with sparkling eyes
will obtain the good girl with the glance of a frightened doe, with moist beauty.
He who approaches without fear of [its] anger the red bull of hot vigour
will obtain sleep on the bamboo-like soft shoulders of [her with] lined earrings,” thus
the herders announce [and] put the good girls
respectfully in a row on top of the platform,
like the moon that is surrounded in the area by the stars of the days.
That way, while drums rise [and] sound, while many people shout,
the bulls, having been set free when a clockwise [circle] has been made with incense,
gore [with the horns] that they raise against the [attempts at] taking [them made] by young men without defect.
See the appearance of the young black bull who does not endure [it and] pierces
the one who leapt onto the neck of the milk-coloured white bull,
unafraid of the opposition from [its] horns with victoriously powerful tips, like spear tips,
after having passed by the arena, descending [and] going upon [it], because of feeling very hostile
towards the upper position of that bull.
It is like the one with blue colour
who makes the snake that is joined to the milky moon release [its] hold.
You saw the graceful bull of unabating anger
that drove away, turned against [and] ravaged the one who had taken it on
so that he perished from its horns, cutting, cutting, breaking, breaking,
[and] piercing [his] so that [his] bowels spilled out,
while many rose in retreat, went away shaking all over [and] left together.
This one is like a murderous elephant bull that turns
in anger when [they] raise frightening smoke.
See the appearance of the spotted bull that returns
without going upon the one who fell in front of it
after having gone for [its] head without giving up the fame for [his] determined grip that rose out of effort,
[then] having abandoned [his] determined grip on the strength of the shoulder, having gone beyond, reached,
He is like one whom Death forgot,
turning away, claiming him one not equal to one controlled by the sword in swift fight.
Thus, while the bull stands against [them], tearing [and] ravaging,
while young men approach refusing, refusing [to yield],
while pieces of flesh break, break [and] lie scattered,
while musical instruments rise [and] roar with thunder-like sound,
with those who take the oncoming bulls, leap [and] mount [them],
those who get in between the horns [and] those who announced [their] taking [them]
the arena is like the battle field
where the Five with line-decorated strong bows killed
to that the Hundred who had gone upon them with a will turned [away].
In the arena, when all the bulls that had been taken had entered the fields,
the good girls of unimpeded excellence and flexible grace and the young men
engage there in embracing [in the Kuravai dance].
Come, let is sing the chest of the herder
on which the horns of the bull made a mark.
“I won’t be content without reaching the wide chest of him who destroyed
the fulness of the red spot on the [bull’s] front, so that the eyes of [my] enemies are lowered.”
While the great people raise a scandal, that strongly
Oh friend, in the Kuravai dance which we dance together, looking as if
he were afraid of us will is not cause [us] the pain of unhappiness,
the pride of the herder’s son who says:
“I took the murderous bull with sparkling eyes.
You with fine jewels, our affectionate people will agree to give [you]
to the herder who leapt without fear of [its] fury on the murderous bull
that was judged to be difficult [to take],
trampling on the heads of the village people who raise gossip.
Thus, let us revere him with the ancient, shining discus,
saying “let this world together without weakening accept
the one word of the Southern king with thunder-like drums.”
